misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop or while-loop that iterates five times, reading one integer each time and processing it inside the loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no loop constructs at all and explicitly reads a fixed number of values.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0) before including it in a sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that computing (v1 - v0) / t is the correct operation, rather than filtering even numbers using a condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Each input integer should be tested with a condition like if (n % 2 == 0) before being added to the running sum.
symptoms: No use of the % operator
No if-statement related to even/odd checks
Computed result is an average acceleration, not a sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment with the problem specification, likely due to copying an average-acceleration example without adding the required conditional logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the loop that reads each integer, add an if (n % 2 == 0) check and only add n to the sum if the condition is true.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional logic or modulus operations anywhere.

System.out.println("The average acceleration is "+a);

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review lessons on `for` loops and `if` statements. Start by setting up a loop to run five times, reading one integer inside the loop, and then using an `if` statement inside the loop to check if that number is even.
